module.p: aig at is the (non-leniting) adessive preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the adessive preposition is simply aig –
aig balla at a wall
aig eaglaisean at churches
aig Tormod at Norman
aig còig craobhan at five trees
However, when the complement of aig is a verbal noun denoting an event or activity in progress, the preposition takes the special form ag, ag ithe (in the process of) eating.

Unlike with some other prepositions, there is no special form of aig used before the definite article –
aig an taigh at the house
aig a’ chraoibh at the tree
aig na h-eaglaisean at the churches

Fused forms are occasionally found when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
aig mo thaigh at my house ≈ gam thaigh
aig do bhaile at your town ≈ gad bhaile
aig a h-eaglais at her church ≈ ga h-eaglais
aig a chraoibh at his tree ≈ ga chraoibh
aig ar n-achadh at our field ≈ gar n-achadh
aig bhur leapannan at your beds ≈ gur leapannan
aig an taighean at their houses ≈ gan taighean
aig am baile at their town ≈ gam baile

Note that these fused forms are often ambiguous and hence are probably best avoided in writing. Note also that, in older texts, you will sometimes find them written with initial apostrophes – ’gam thaigh, ’gad bhaile, ...

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of aig mi, aig thu, ... , aig iad –
agam at me
agad at you
aice at her/it
aige at him/it
againn at us
agaibh at you
aca at them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. aig mise, aig thusa, ... , aig iadsan) –
agamsa at me
agadsa at you
aicese at her/it
aigesan at him/it
againne at us
agaibhse at you
acasan at them
Note that the form aigesan breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – aige-san.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. aig mi fhìn, aig thu fhèin, ... , aig iad fhèin) –
agam fhìn at myself
agad fhèin at yourself
aice fhèin at herself/itself
aige fhèin at himself/itself
againn fhìn at ourselves
agaibh fhèin at yourself
aca fhèin at themselves
Like all (true) prepositions, aig governs a noun complement in the dative case.
These complements can belong to a number of different semantic classes.

When the complement of aig denotes a human, they usually play the role of possessor of something –
aig Eilidh in Helen’s possession
aig a’ chailleach in the old woman’s possession
againn in our possession

The nature of the possessive relationship depends on the nature of the possession itself –

Mary didn’t have enough money. | James hasn’t got a penny. | I have enough. | Did you do your work? | And what’s your job there? | I heard her voice, I thought. | Mary will not go on holiday even though she will have the money. | And wasn’t there a parliamentary election in France? – Yes, and they elected a new president for their parliament. | Will they get their holidays tomorrow? | Ann doesn’t know what happened. | They have songs galore. | What plans would you have for Gaelic learners in Scotland today? That would keep their Gaelic fluent and active. td. 15 | 5 | 35 | 37 | 66 | 50 | 105 | 83 | 197 | 78 | 116 | 150

all that I have/possess | He had plenty of money. td. 15 | ibid
examples from Gairm –
Bha beagan airgid aige ’s mar sin chaith e a bheatha a’ sgrìobhadh, gun feum aige air obair eile a dhèanamh.
He had a little money and therefore he devoted his life to writing, without the need to do other work. td. 103

When the complement of aig denotes an inanimate object, like an artifact or a geographical feature, it usually marked the reference point for a physical location –
aig taigh solais [located] at a lighthouse
aig an eas [located] at the waterfall

Some examples –
artifacts –
pedagogical examples –
Bha iad nan suidhe aig bòrd mòr. | Tha [an siùcar] thall an sin aig an doras. | Bha mi aig an taigh Diluain. | aig balla | aig geata | aig an uinneig
They were sitting at a large table. | [The sugar] is over there at the door. | I was at home on Monday. | at a wall | at a gate | at the window td. 14 | 34 | 39 | 62 | 196 | 69
Chunnaic mi cù aig an dorus.
I saw a dog at the door. td. 6
geographical features –
pedagogical examples –
Bha [sinn] gu tric air Loch na Creige agus aig Linne na Ciste.
[We] were often on Loch na Creige and at Linne na Ciste. td. 99

When the complement of aig denotes a space or place, the sense is again locative –
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. [...] td. 6–7

When the complement of aig denotes a social occasion or event, it marks the location of attendance –
aig a’ bhanais [located] at [the place where] the wedding [is happening]

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
An robh thu aig a’ chèilidh? | Chuala sinn Anna a’ seinn aig a’ chèilidh a-raoir.
Were you at the ceilidh? | We heard Ann singing at the ceilidh last night. td. 40 | 58

When the complement of aig denotes a clock time (or equivalent), the sense is a temporal locative –
aig ceithir uairean at 4 o’clock
aig meadhan latha at noon

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
aig deireadh an latha | aig seachd uairean
at the end of the day | at seven o’clock td. 14 | ibid
Nach fhalbhadh Anna aig dà uair? | Nam biodh tu ann aig deich uairean dh’fhalbhadh sinn còmhla.
Wouldn’t Ann leave at two o’clock? | If you were there at ten o’clock we would leave together. td. 136 | 138

One common use of the preposition aig is to introduce the predicate of the verb bi –
Tha Seònaid aig an taigh sholais. Shona is at the lighthouse.
Tha each ùr againn. We have a new horse.
Bidh a’ chèilidh aig ochd uairean. The ceilidh will be at eight o’clock.
Some specific subtypes of predicate relation are described in the following sections.

Predicative aig can be used to state the (adessive) location of an entity with respect to another (concrete or abstract) entity –
Càite a bheil Seònaid? Where is Shona?
Tha i aig a’ charragh chuimhne chogaidh. She is at the war memorial.
Tha i aig an loch. She is at the loch.
Tha i aig adhlacadh Nèill. She is at Neil’s funeral.

Some examples –
at a physical object –
pedagogical examples –
Tha [an siùcar] thall an sin aig an doras. | Bha mi aig an taigh Diluain.
[The sugar] is over there at the door. | I was at home on Monday. td. 34 | 39
at a geographical feature –
pedagogical examples –
An robh sibh ag iasgach còmhla riutha? – Bha [agus sinn] gu tric air Loch na Creige agus aig Linne na Ciste.
Were you fishing along with them? – Yes, often on Loch na Creige and at Linne na Ciste. td. 99
at a social occasion –
pedagogical examples –
An robh thu aig a’ chèilidh?
Were you at the ceilidh? td. 40

Predicative aig can be used to state the possessor of an entity –
Cò aige a tha am bàta seo? Whose is this boat?
Tha e aig Dòmhnall. It is Donald’s.
Dè a tha aig Màiri? What does Mary have?
Tha cuilean aice. She has a puppy.

Some examples –

vehicles –
pedagogical examples –

I have a boat. Donald has a car. td. 14–5

pedagogical examples –

Predicative aig can be used to state the location of an event in clock time –
Cùine a bhios a’ choinneamh? / Dè an uair a bhios a’ choinneamh? When / at what time will the meeting be?
Bidh i aig uair. It will be at one o’clock.

Predicative aig can be used to state that someone knows something –
Tha Gàidhlig aig Raonaid. Rachel knows Gaelic.
Tha fios aca gu bheil Màiri pòsta. They know that Mary is married.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Seinnidh Pàdraig agus Catrìona co-dhiù. Tha òrain gu leòr acasan. | Chumadh sin a’ Ghàidhlig [a tha] aca fileanta fuasgailte.
Patrick and Catherine will sing anyway. They have songs galore. | That would keep their Gaelic fluent and active. td. 116 | 150

See also –
bi fios aig ... know that ...
bi sgeul air ... aig ... know where something is

Some idioms –
bi feum air ... aig ... need something

Miscellaneous predicative examples –
pedagogical examples –
Gu robh math agad/agaibh!
Thank you! td. 59 [176]

The aig prepositional pronouns are occasionally found used as the complement of a quantity noun, with a partitive meaning, as an alternative to the more usual dhe of –
mòran aca many of them
seachdnar aca seven of them

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Bha dithis(t) aca ann. | Dh’iarainn gum biodh cuid aca air a’ Ghàidhealtachd a chionn is gur h-ann an sin as motha a tha a’ Ghàidhlig beò.
There were two of them there. | I would want some of them to be in the Gaelic speaking area since that is where Gaelic is most alive. td. 150

Some examples as a verbal complement –
Chunnaic mi cù aig an dorus.
I saw a dog at the door. td. 6

Another common use of the preposition aig is to introduce a modifier of a verb or noun –
Lorg Raonaid an cù aig an taigh sholais. Rachel found the dog at the lighthouse.
a’ choinneamh aig còig uairean the meeting at five o’clock

The preposition aig can introduce locative and temporal modifiers of verbs –
Dh’òladh Raonaid fìon dearg aig an taigh. Rachel would drink red wine at home.
Bha Dòmhnall a’ leughadh aig leth uair an dèidh seachd uairean. Donald was reading at half past seven.

Some examples –
locative modifiers –
pedagogical examples –
Bha iad nan suidhe aig bòrd mòr.
They were sitting at a large table. td. 14
An robh sibh ag iasgach còmhla riutha? – Bha gu tric air Loch na Creige agus aig Linne na Ciste. | Dh’innis Iain dhomh gur h-e Màiri a sheinn aig a’ chèilidh.
Were you fishing along with them? – Yes, often on Loch na Creige and at Linne na Ciste. | John told me that it was Mary who sang at the ceilidh. td. 99 | 145
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. [...] td. 6–7
temporal modifiers –
pedagogical examples –

Wouldn’t Ann leave at two o’clock? | If you were there at ten o’clock we would leave together. td. 136 | 138

The preposition aig can introduce locative, possessive and temporal modifiers of nouns –
Thàinig am fear aig an doras a-steach. The man at the door came in.
Tha an cù againn anns a’ ghàrradh. Our dog is in the garden.
Tha mi an·seo airson na coinneimhe aig deich uairean. I am here for the meeting at ten o’clock.

Some examples –
possessive –
pedagogical examples –
an leabhar aig Seumas | an cat agam | Is e Seumas (an duine) as sine anns an teaghlach aige. | A bheil a’ bhròg agad ro theann? | Chumadh sin a’ Ghàidhlig aca fileanta fuasgailte.
James’ book | my cat | James is the eldest in his family. | Is your shoe too tight? | That would keep their Gaelic fluent and active. td. 85| 14 | 198 | 19 | 150
Various other uses of aig as a modifier are found.
